discussion.content:
Components of Posture Services
Cisco ISE posture service primarily includes the posture administration services and the posture run-time services. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/ise/2-2/admin_guide/b_ise_admin_guide_22/b_ise_admin_guide_22_chapter_010111.html#concept_60EFB79F4CF144B4B1E691FBE89399F5

questions.question_text: Which two services are included in the Cisco ISE posture service? (Choose two.)

choices.C: an ACL that points traffic to the Cisco ISE deployment
choices.B: Cisco NAC Agents that communicate with the Cisco ISE server
choices.A: at least one Cisco router to store Cisco ISE profiling policies
choices.D: the advanced license package must be installed

questions.question_text: What is a requirement for posture administration services in Cisco ISE?

discussion.content:
Enable Posture Session Service in Cisco ISE
 You must enable session services in Cisco ISE and install the advanced license package to serve all the posture requests received from the clients. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/ise/2-2/admin_guide/b_ise_admin_guide_22/b_ise_admin_guide_22_chapter_010111.html#concept_837634A10070454BB54D8B110C66AC7D

questions.question_text: Which two statements about Cisco NAC Agents that are installed on clients that interact with the Cisco ISE profiler are true? (Choose two.)

choices.E: They store endpoints in the Cisco ISE with their profiles.
choices.D: They block access from the network through noncompliant endpoints.
choices.F: They evaluate clients against posture policies, to enforce requirements.
choices.A: They send endpoint data to AAA servers.
choices.C: They interact with the posture service to enforce endpoint security policies.

discussion.content: This question is wrong. Posture has nothing todo with the profiler service.

questions.question_text: In the command 'aaa authentication default group tacacs local', how is the word 'default' defined?
What steps must you perform to deploy a CA-signed identify certificate on an ISE device?

choices.B: 1. Download the CA server certificate. 2. Generate a signing request and save it as a file. 3. Access the CA server and submit the ISE request. 4. Install the issued certificate on the CA server.
choices.C: 1. Generate a signing request and save it as a file. 2. Download the CA server certificate. 3. Access the ISE server and submit the CA request. 4. Install the issued certificate on the CA server.
choices.D: 1. Generate a signing request and save it as a file. 2. Download the CA server certificate. 3. Access the CA server and submit the ISE request.
choices.A: 1. Download the CA server certificate. 2. Generate a signing request and save it as a file. 3. Access the CA server and submit the ISE request. 4. Install the issued certificate on the ISE.

discussion.content: Correct answer should be A. D would be correct if it had 4. Install the issued certificate on the ISE.
agree, the answer is A, the option D missing the step "Access the CA server and submit the ISE request."
Surely Answer is A. You need to install the CA issued ISE cert at some point. You do this by 'binding' the CA-signed cert to the ISE CSR you generated.

Cisco ISE Administrator Guide 2.6 page 164:
Certificate Signing Requests
For a certificate authority (CA) to issue a signed certificate, you must create a certificate signing request (CSR)
and submit it to the CA.
The list of Certificate Signing Requests (CSRs) that you have created is available in the Certificate Signing
Requests page. To obtain signatures from a Certificate Authority (CA), you must export the CSRs and then
send the certificates to the CA. The CA signs and returns your certificates.
You can manage the certificates centrally from the Admin portal. You can create CSRs for all nodes in the
deployment and export them. Then you should submit the CSRs to a CA, obtain the CA-signed certificates
from the CA, import the root and intermediary CA certificates returned by the CA in to the Trusted Certificates
Store, and bind the CA-signed certificates to the CSRs.
